tool.name: Excel to MultiFASTA MIST Preparation
tool.description: Parses a minimal two column csv or excel file to retrieve data from NCBI with one column and renaming the header of a multifasta with the other column

param.name: api_key
param.label: NCBI API Key
param.help: NCBI API Keys enable users to have an increased request limit connecting to NCBI.

param.name: use_name_col
param.label: Relabel with ENTIRE name column
param.help: Use this if you want the ENTIRE name column to be used for header replacement

tool.help:
Description ------------- This tool reorders the header of a fasta for use with MIST. The input is either a CSV or Excel file. Minimally the file needs: a column that you want to have as the new name for the header, which is what will be used for MIST in representing the genome, and an accession column, which is used for retrieving and generating the multifasta from NCBI.
There are two methods that the header is reorganized.
* **OPTION 1:** The "Relabel with ENTIRE name column" switch, when on, will use the name column as the replacement text for the header. It will put '_' between spaces. The accession will be added with a space after the name in the header of that genome in the fasta. * **OPTION 2:** The "Relabel with ENTIRE name column" switch is off (to no). This will cause a specific pattern to be parsed. Which is the following: Search through the value in the name column. If the second word is 'phage', 'virus', or 'ecoli', grab all words following them, otherwise grab everything from the first word and beyond. Similarly to the other method, if there is more than one word, combine with a '_' and then tack on the accession after the new name for the header. If more options are desired, they can be added by request via GitHub.
MIST uses the first "word" of the header of a fasta for labeling, which when used with a multifasta from this tool, will result in the allowance of controlling the labeling for MIST plots.
Lastly, when errors arise from running this tool in conjunction with MIST, a issue might be the diverse size of genomes. When MIST is given genomes of different sizes (say 4kb v. 100kb), it struggles to do a pairwise comparison. When this occurs, it is advised to filter out those genomes.
**note: The NCBI API Key is optional. CPT has their own key which will be used if user's do not have their own**
